original_title: Sri Lanka rupee closes down at 320/328 to US dollar
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s rupee closed down at 320/328 to the US dollar in the spot market Monday down from 319/321 on Friday, dealers said.
The rupee opened around 318/328 to the US dollar and business was done at around 323 and 325 levels, dealers said.
In late trading the rupee was quoted around 327/330 to the US dollar.
There was heavy selling after the rupee started to appreciate over the past two weeks and banks were also selling down their open positions.
On March 16 there is a 202 million dollar Sri Lanka Development Bond maturity, based on official data, which, when paid in rupees, will also hit bank open positions.
As a result, there is demand from trading activities, dealer said.
Sri Lanka’s private credit is negative and in January there was a 211 million US dollar balance of payments surplus.
In February also there was about a 200 million dollar net purchases by the central bank or averaging about 10 million dollars a day.
Amid heavy selling the central bank has about 500 million US dollar following the lifting of a surrender rule.

Sri Lanka is operating an ad hoc peg called a ‘flexible exchange rate’ where the monetary intervenes here and there to stop what it calls excessive volatility and also targets a domestic inflation index with open market operations.
Similar arrangements with a variety of inflation targets are found in recently defaulting countries. (Colombo/Mar13/2023)
